context: [3] Here, we noticed that Phe432 in the compound 1 cocrystal structure adopts the same conformation as in the apo form. [4] When compared with the reported structures of arachidonyl inhibitor MAFP in rat FAAH (PDB code: 1MT5) and piperidine-urea compound PF-750 in a humanized rat FAAH chimera (PDB code: 2VYA) (â€“), compound 1 shows the same covalent mode of inactivation, in which the urea carbonyl is attacked by Ser241, despite the evident difference in the chemical structures of these covalent adducts. [5] Furthermore, the adducts from these ligands, attached to the catalytic Ser241, follow a similar path toward the united portion of the MAC and ABP and make extensive van der Waals contacts with numerous hydrophobic residues in this proximal portion of the active site. [1] In summary, the structural data revealed that compound 1 inhibits FAAH through urea carbonyl acylation of the catalytic nucleophile Ser241 with the 2-fluoroaniline moiety as the leaving group (Fig.Â 3C). [2] Compound 1 behaves as a suicide substrate inhibitor. [1] Following the characterization of the HTS lead compound 1, we initiated a structure-based medicinal chemistry effort to design unique active-site inhibitors. [2] We were particularly interested in noncovalent or reversible covalent compounds, as they might bring enhanced selectivity and fewer unwanted side effects than any of the known covalent inhibitors.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, urea is involved in the mechanism of inhibition of fatty acid amide hydrolase (FAAH) by compound 1, which contains the 2-fluoroaniline moiety. The urea carbonyl is acylated by the catalytic nucleophile Ser241, with 2-fluoroaniline acting as the leaving group. This indicates a direct chemical interaction where urea plays a crucial role in the inhibition process, highlighting its significance in the compound's mechanism of action.
